Mirror symmetry is a powerful tool in enumerating rational curves on a quintic threefold. A quintic threefold is a complex algebraic variety defined by a homogeneous polynomial of degree 5 in four complex projective coordinates. The problem of counting rational curves on a quintic threefold can be translated into a problem in Gromov-Witten theory, which deals with counting holomorphic curves in a given symplectic manifold.

Using mirror symmetry, we can relate the problem of counting rational curves on a quintic threefold to the problem of counting periods on its mirror manifold. The mirror manifold of a quintic threefold is a certain family of Calabi-Yau manifolds, which are complex algebraic varieties with trivial canonical bundle. The periods of the mirror manifold are certain integrals of holomorphic 3-forms, and they can be computed using the Picard-Fuchs equations.

The number of rational curves of degree d on a quintic threefold can be computed using the so-called "Gromov-Witten invariants." These invariants are certain intersection numbers on the moduli space of stable maps, which are maps from a Riemann surface (in this case, a rational curve) to the quintic threefold that satisfy certain stability conditions.

The Gromov-Witten invariants can be computed using the mirror symmetry techniques by relating them to the periods of the mirror manifold. In particular, the generating function of the Gromov-Witten invariants can be expressed in terms of the periods of the mirror manifold. This generating function is a power series whose coefficients are the Gromov-Witten invariants, and it can be computed using the Picard-Fuchs equations.

For a quintic threefold, the generating function of the Gromov-Witten invariants is given by the following formula:

F(q) = ∑_{d=1}^∞ N_d q^d,

In conclusion, the number of rational curves on a quintic threefold can be computed using mirror symmetry techniques by relating the problem to the computation of periods on its mirror manifold.
